subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Earnings from Mitsubishi Motors and Sharp, BoJ to hold off-schedule meeting on Friday, China is reportedly considering further action against Australia
content:
AUSTRALIA

Boral (BLD AT) - Co. faces a AUD 700mln lawsuit in US from a former owner of a windows business it acquired. (The Australian)

Decmil Group (DCG AT) - Reports note speculation capital raise could be priced at a 50% discount. (AFR)

Evolution Mining (EVN AT) - Co. is expected to sell Mount Carlton and Mount Rawdon mines. (Newswires)

Sydney Airport (SYD AT) - Co. total April passengers fell 97.5% Y/Y to 92K. (Newswires)

TPG Telecom (TPG AT) - Vodafone Australia secured over AUD 5bln of funding for the new group formed by merger with TPG. (The Australian)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT) - Co. is said to be considering a government bailout to fund the remainder of its sale process. (Newswires)

WorleyParsons (WOR AT) - Co. enters into 2 global framework agreements with BP (BP/ LN). (Newswires)

Healthcare - Australia government is to raise fundung for medical research by AUD 400mln. (Newswires)

Trade - China government is reportedly to consider tighter quality checks, delayed customs clearances, anti dumping probes or boycott targetting items such as Australian wine and dairy poducts amid virus dispute. (Newswires)

Other News - Australia's New South Wales will lift travel restrictions from June 1st. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Citizen Watch (7762 JT) - Co. FY net loss JPY 16.7bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 13.4bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Fujifilm (4901 JT) - Co.’s Avigan is reportedly not showing apparent efficacy as a coronavirus treatment. (Kyodo)

Mitsubishi Motors (7211 JT) - Co. FY net loss JPY 25.8bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 132.9bln Y/Y, does not provide guidance. (Newswires)

Nippon Yusen (9101 JT) - Co. may report FY oper. profit around JPY 45bln vs. guidance of JPY 37bln. (Nikkei)

Panasonic (6752 JT) - Co. to reesume battery production at Tesla’s (TSLA) New Yprk factory this week. (Newswires)

Sharp (6753 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 21.0bln vs. Prev. JPY 74.2bln Y/Y, rev. JPY 2.27tln vs. Prev. JPY 2.40tln, aims to provide guidance in August. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT) - Co. will integrate its financial unit and will become Sony Group. (Nikkei)

Other News

Japanese government are to set up a JPY 50bln fund with the private sector, designed to inject capital into small & mid-sized firms. (Nikkei)

BoJ is to hold an off-schedule meeting on May 22nd at 0900JST/0100BST in which the purpose of the meeting is to discuss a possible new measure to provide funds to financial institutions. (BoJ)

Note: BoJ Governor Kuroda had previously ordered staff to prepare a plan to spur financial institutions to boost lending to firms impacted by the coronavirus and stated that they would like to proceed with getting the plan ready before the next meeting in June even if that means holding an emergency policy meeting.

 

SOUTH KOREA

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. unveiled new image sensors with faster autofocus. (Yonhap)

Other News - South Korean Finance Minister Hong said they need to aggressively create jobs and that measures to create jobs will be central to bi-annual economic policy plan due early next month, while South Korea is to create KRW 10tln fund to buy corporate bonds and with the program to be expanded to KRW 20tln if needed. (Newswires)

subject: RBNZ buys NZD 450mln in government bonds as part of QE
RBA adds AUD 891mln to the banking system through repos vs. Prev. AUD 400mln
RBNZ Governor Orr says strategy is to keep yield curve low and flat, adds they are prepared to go negative but not at this time and a lot later
RBA says excess cash at exchange settlement accounts at AUD 68.6bln vs. Prev. AUD 69.2bln
LA County is unlikely to reopen widely until at least July 4th, according to the County Supervisor
Lenovo (992 HK) Q4 net USD 43mln vs. Prev. USD 118mln Y/Y, rev. USD 10.6bln vs. Prev. USD 11.7bln Y/Y

South Korean Finance Minister Hong says need to aggressively create jobs and that measures to create jobs will be central to bi annual economic policy plan due early next month, adds to create KRW 10tln fund to buy corporate bonds
content: Program will be expanded to KRW 20tln if needed.

subject: ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES ARE AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include New Zealand Food Prices, Japanese Machine Orders and PBoC Loan Prime Rate
Australia's New South Wales says to lift travel restrictions from June 1st
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

An EU resolution calling for coronavirus inquiry has been adopted by consensus at the WHO, while US said it supports the EU resolution at WHO and that calling for a COVID inquiry is a critical step to ensure there is a WHO and an international system capable of responding effectively to the next pandemic. (Newswires)

Chinese Foreign Ministry said US President Trump’s letter to the WHO attempts to mislead public to smear China and tries to shift blame of its own "incompetent" response, while there were also comments from China WHO envoy that US support for Taiwan amounts to political hype and that this conduct is not acceptable. (Newswires)

New York Governor Cuomo said the capital region in the Eastern and Central part of the state will reopen on Wednesday, becoming the seventh region to reopen. (Newswires)

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said over the next couple of weeks he will assess the need for additional coronavirus aid legislation, while House GOP Leader McCarthy does not see the need right now for another relief bill. However, FBN's Gasparino noted there is reportedly a growing congressional consensus on another round of stimulus after Memorial Day and possibly as much as USD 1 trillion. (CNN/Fox Business News)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose to 35,341 (Prev. 34,796) which is an increase of 545 vs. Prev. increase of 160. (Newswires)

Moderna (MRNA) COVID-19 vaccine reportedly did not produce data critical to assessing the vaccine, according to STAT News citing experts. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

China is likely to end the precedent of an providing a specific figure for the GDP growth target in the upcoming two-sessions meeting, according to a survey of economists. (Global Times)

China will push ahead with listings of domestic companies in London as it seeks to move away from US amid an escalation in tensions. (SCMP)

Japanese government are to set up a JPY 50bln fund with the private sector, designed to inject capital into small & mid-sized firms. (Nikkei)

BoJ to hold an off-schedule meeting on May 22nd at 0900JST/0100BST in which the purpose of the meeting is to discuss a possible new measure to provide funds to financial institutions. (BoJ) Note: BoJ Governor Kuroda had previously ordered staff to prepare a plan to spur financial institutions to boost lending to firms impacted by the coronavirus and stated that they would like to proceed with getting the plan ready before the next meeting in June even if that means holding an emergency policy meeting.

Singapore is mulling a three-phase reopening from June 2nd and will unveil more support measures on May 26th, while it expects a third of the workforce to resume on-site work from June 2nd. Furthermore, it expects easing of curbs will see 75% of the Singapore economy to resume normal operations but also anticipates a daily rise in cases as activities resume. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson spokesman said the full details on quarantine plan will be published when possible, while No10 is said to push back on the "air bridges" plan. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Sunak said it is not obvious there will be an immediate bounce back after COVID and commented that employer contribution to the furlough schemes should be set at a level that will not result in avoidable redundancies, while he sees no need to further expand business loans. (Newswires)

UK Cabinet Office Minister Gove Said there are still differences between the UK and EU on fishing rights but added that a zero tariff, zero quota deal is still possible. Gove also reiterated that the government will not extend transition period and Northern Ireland approach will be outlined shortly. (Newswires)

Germany Foreign Minister Maas is confident that he can convince other EU nations over the Coronavirus Recovery Fund, while there were comments from French Finance Minister Le Maire that the EU recovery fund will not be available until 2021. (Newswires)

ECB's Lane said the ECB is fully prepared to further adjust instruments if needed including increasing PEPP size and tweaking composition as much as needed, while he added that the APP and PEPP expected to compress term premium by ~80bps at the 10yr tenor. Furthermore, Lane reiterated that in all scenarios, a deep recession is envisaged and that in the severe scenario, real GDP would fall by 12% in 2020. (Newswires)

European Commission Executive Vice-President Dombrovskis said the Commission will propose instruments for structural reforms aside from cash for the recovery and later stated that the recovery instrument proposal will surpass EUR 1tln comprised of a mix of loans and grants. Furthermore, he added the Commission is exploring the possibility of using some funds this year and suggested it is not straightforward. (Newswires)

  • German ZEW Economic Sentiment (May) 51.0 vs. Exp. 32.0 (Prev. 28.2)
  • German ZEW Current Conditions (May) -93.5 vs. Exp. -88.0 (Prev. -91.5)
  • EU ZEW Survey Expectations (May) 46.0 (Prev. 25.2)

 

COMMODITIES

Standard Chartered raised gold price forecast to USD 1689/oz for 2020 and sees prices averaging USD 1750/oz In Q4. (Twitter)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US ordered all foreign military ships to maintain a 100-meter distance in international waters. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump said he will sign executive orders on regulation and is directing US agencies to review suspended regulations and make them permanent where possible. Trump also stated that the US should consider terminating trade deals under which it imports cattle, while he also said he is talking to Canada about relaxing the ban on non-essential trade. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US continues to see large unemployment and other negative economic indicators in Q2 but sees conditions improving in Q3 and Q4 as businesses return to work, while he later commented that a reduction in taxes for middle class households should be "seriously considered". (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow repeated there will be a painful COVID contraction and that there needs to be pro-growth incentives for the US economy, while he added that President Trump wants a 7.6% payroll tax cut and that he does not think China will sell US debt. (Newswires)

Fed's Chair Powell said they are continuing to look into ways to accommodate additional borrowers and are particularly looking at extending borrowing to states with low populations. Powell also stated he expects the balance sheet to gradually shrink over time and that what matters is the size of the balance sheet relative to the size of the US economy, while he added that the balance sheet does not yet raise financial stability concerns. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (voter. dove) said that US GDP growth is probably one or two years away and that the US has extraordinary fiscal capacity to borrow and spend what is needed to get through the current crisis. (Newswires)

Fed's Rosengren (non-voter, hawk) says policymakers will do whatever they can to support the return to full employment; says the unemployment rate will likely remain at double digit levels by year-end

Nasdaq reportedly delivered notice to Luckin Coffee (LK) that it must delist according to sources and Luckin plans to request a hearing to appeal. (Newswires)

subject: US extends ban on non-essential travel with Mexico and Canada to June 22nd

White House economic adviser Kudlow says US President Trump is not saying he was tearing up the China trade deal, adds President Trump is in a bad place over China's virus mistakes and that China must be held accountable
White House economic adviser Kudlow reiterates sees some early glimpses of a recovery, adds lets get middle class tax cuts and make good trade deals
White House Economic Advisor Hassett says they are watching and planning if more stimulus is needed after the COVID-19 outbreak, according to Fox News interview
Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) announces discontinuation of talc-based baby powder in US and Canada

subject: CDC reports US total COVID cases +1.7% D/D at 1.504mln (prev. 1.480mln)
Newsquawk US Market Wrap - May 19th: Stocks reverse gains after vaccine hopes knocked
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

May 19th: Stocks reverse gains after vaccine hopes knocked

·        SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude mixed.

·        REARVIEW: MRNA vaccine concerns highlighted; strong WMT Q1 amid COVID-demand, HD bottom-line hit due to COVID-expenses; China to move away from US stock listings; potential progress on next US stimulus bill.

·        COMING UP: Data: UK, EZ & Canadian CPI, EZ Consumer Confidence, Australian PMIs. Event: FOMC Minutes, Riksbank Financial Stability Report. Speakers: BoE Governor Bailey. Supply: France, UK, German & US. Earnings: Target & Analog Devices.

MARKET WRAP

After a choppy start amid further negative US/China headlines, stocks had managed to add to gains, with consumer discretionary and communications leading (energy and financials lagged); momentum and growth baskets were performing well, while dividend, min vol and size strategies were lower. However, it got a little hairy in afternoon trade, on negative news flow about Moderna’s COVID vaccine, which saw bourses move significantly into the red. Prior to the slide, the Dow was lagging the S&P 500 and Nasdaq-100 after downside in energy names, as well as WMT and HD trading lower after earnings. The dollar is a touch lower, which has allowed pretty much everything else to rise against it; notably commodity FX was putting in a strong show, despite crude settling mixed (and on little news flow); risk-sensitive FX also had a decent session. Treasury yields are lower, but major curve spreads are mixed (2s5s and 2s10s slightly narrower, while 2s30s,, 5s10s, 5s30s and 10s30s all a touch wider); some desks had suggested that the steepening, particularly in 5s30s was a function of concession ahead of the return of 20-year Treasury supply on Wednesday. Fed’s Powell and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin didn’t have any major updates in their testimony to Senate lawmakers.

VACCINE

MODERNA (MRNA) COVID-19 vaccine reportedly did not produce data critical to assessing the vaccine, according to a STAT News report citing experts. The piece didn’t provide new details necessarily of the Phase 1 results presented yesterday, which had been supporting risk assets, but it instead phrased the results in a more cautious tone, noting the problems with the eight-person sample size used in the study. Elsewhere, a study completed by UnitedHealth (UNH) with Yale Medicine School has found that elderly COVID-19 patients taking hypertension medication are at lower risk of hospitalisation and a clinical trial is to follow immediately.

NORTH AMERICA

TRADE: US President Trump said the US should consider terminating trade deals under which it imports cattle. The remarks were made in reference to a new USD 19bln farmer aid programme, which is likely a campaign effort for farmers ahead of the elections. Trump also said he is talking to Canada about relaxing the ban on non-essential trade. The US Chamber of Commerce also said today that protecting the resiliency of US supply chains does not mean having to reshore all production to the US – note, AAPL announced it was shifting earphone production to Vietnam.

WHO/CHINA: Chinese Foreign Ministry, regarding US President Trump’s letter to WHO, said the US’ letter attempts to mislead public, to smear China and tries to shift the blame of its own “incompetent” response. This came after US President Trump criticised the World Health Organization in which he stated it has done a sad job and is a puppet of China, while he is to make a decision soon and was considering reducing the US contribution to the WHO to USD 40mln (currently around USD 400mln) but said some felt that was too much. Furthermore, he later shared the letter he sent to the WHO which warned if they do not commit to substantive improvements within next 30 days, the US will permanently freeze its funding and reconsider membership.

CHINESE STOCK LISTINGS: China will push ahead with listings of domestic companies in London, as its seeks to move away from US amid an escalation in tensions, SCMP reported. “In a revival of the virtually suspended cross-border investment programme, Beijing will resume vetting applications by Chinese companies looking to sell global depository receipts (GDR) on the London Stock Exchange (LSE) through a link with the Shanghai bourse, according to a source familiar with the matter.” Earlier, sources had noted that Nasdaq is said to be tightening listing rules and restricting IPOs of Chinese companies. Nasdaq has not yet confirmed the reports, although it did announce the delisting of Luckin Coffee (LK) amid the accounting scandals at the Chinese Co.

STIMULUS: US President Trump said he had a good meeting with Republican senators and that progress was made on many issues. Meanwhile, US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said over the next couple of weeks he will assess the need for additional coronavirus aid legislation; additionally, GOP Leader McCarthy does not see the need right now for another relief bill, CNN reported. FBN’s Gasparino reported that there is a growing congressional consensus on another round of stimulus after Memorial Day, possibly as much as USD 1 trillion. Note, the House Democrats tabled a USD 3trln bill although the Senate is very unlikely to accept this as many Republicans have expressed opposition to it as many GOP’s want to see how the current stimulus plays out, and some believed the Democrats were attempting to use it as a way of funding their desired policies. Morgan Stanley’s analysts have a base case that the next tranche of stimulus will be sized at between USD 700bln to USD 1.1trln - short of the USD 3trln that the House Bill passed Friday is looking for; Morgan Stanley said that, in a bull case, they can see between USD 1.6trln to USD 2.4trln size. Meanwhile, NEC Director Kudlow said in an FBN interview that the White House looking a corporate tax cut; need to wait and see on payroll protection program changes to relax rules. Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that a reduction in taxes for middle class households should be “seriously considered”.

EUROPE

RECOVERY FUND: European Commission Executive Vice-President Dombrovskis said the recovery instrument proposal will surpass EUR 1tln, comprised of a mix of loans and grants; Commission is exploring the possibility of using some funds this year, it’s not straightforward. It was earlier reported in April noted that Spain is to propose EUR 1.5tln backed by perpetual bonds, other reports in said the EU recovery plan could trigger EUR 2tln of spending and investment. It was also earlier reported of a touted Recovery Fund launch date in 2021, some fear this could be hit less resilient economies, namely the likes of Italy, Spain, Greece. Meanwhile, French Finance Minister Le Maire said the EU recovery fund will not be available until 2021. Looking ahead, the official EU proposal is to be unveiled on May 27th, and European Council President Michel has to broker final accord, with a meeting yet to be scheduled.

CENTRAL BANKS

POWELL TESTIMONY: Nothing too new in Powell’s remarks infront of the Senate Banking Committee today. However, the Fed Chair did say that the Fed is continuing to look into ways to accommodate additional borrowers, and is particularly looking at extending borrowing to states with low populations. Powell said he expects the balance sheet to gradually shrink over time; what matters is the size of the balance sheet relative to the size of the US economy, and the balance sheet does not yet raise financial stability concerns.

FED SPEAK: Kashkari (voter, dove) said that US GDP growth is probably one or two years away; US has extraordinary fiscal capacity to borrow/spend what is needed to get through the current crisis. Rosengren (non-voter, hawk) said policymakers will do whatever they can to support the return to full employment; the unemployment rate will likely remain at double digit levels by year-end.

ECB: Lane said the ECB is fully prepared to further adjust instruments if needed, including increasing PEPP size and tweaking composition as much as needed. Lane said the APP and PEPP are expected to compress term premium by ~80bps at the 10yr tenor. Reiterated that in all scenarios, a deep recession is envisaged: in the severe scenario, real GDP would fall by 12% in 2020.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 8+ TICKS HIGHER AT 138-27+

Treasury yields were lower across the curve, and major curve spreads were mixed on Tuesday; 2s unchanged at 17bp, 10s –3bp at 71bp, and 30s -2bp at 144bp. After the chunky UST sell off on Monday, real money was said to have lifting offers across the curve in the APAC session (yield thirsty Japanese funds have been noted as the marginal buyer in recent weeks as FX hedging costs declined). However, as US participants returned, hedge fund reallocation flows were said by one desk to have continued to exert pressure on USTs, creating somewhat of a tug-of-war with buyers in Asia. Some suggested that the long-end underperformance was a function of concession heading into Wednesday’s sale of new 20-year bonds.

US 20-YEAR BOND AUCTION PREVIEW: At its quarterly refunding announcement, the US Treasury said it would finally issue its new 20-year maturities on 20th May, for a size of USD 20bln (cue ‘20-20-20’ “jokes”). The size was bigger than anticipated (USD 12-14bln was touted), and with heavier supply at the long-end of the curve, combined with no announcement of a 4- or 6-year tenor, resulted in sharp curve steepening in the wake of the announcement, though this has been pared somewhat as risk conditions soften in recent trade. UBS estimates that the market has cheapened the 20-year sector, noting that the sector was cheap versus 10s30s curve as well, although now seems fair; hence, UBS says, it is cheap outright. “In general, we think the sector has already been cheap due to less liquidity and the fact that the Fed owns a large portion of the issues in the 20-year sector so its future purchases are limited.” The bank argues that, given where the 3.375% May 2044 bond is trading, fair value for the 20-year issue is implied at around 1.27%; If we assume 1-2bps of liquidity premia for the new issue, the issue is likely to trade at 1.26%, the bank writes, speculating that the issue should see strong demand since a lot of indexers and Asset Liability Management hedgers will need to buy it. “You can pick-up a lot of yield as the steepest part of 10s30s curve (around 70bps) where fair value is actually 10s20s curve (60bps),” UBS says, noting that the 30-year bond has a duration of 23-years, and comparatively, the 20-year will have a duration of 17.6yrs (5.4yrs shorter), and therefore, it makes more sense to extend duration with a 20-year than a 30- year. “Clearly, if the roll opens cheap to our fair-value estimate, we recommend owning the WI vs comparator,” UBS writes, “post-auction on Wednesday May 20th, into month-end, we recommend putting on 10s20s curve flatteners,” adding that we are likely to see larger than normal index extension because of heavy long-end issuance this month.”

CRUDE

WTI (N0) SETTLED USD 0.31 HIGHER AT USD 31.96; BRENT (N0) SETTLED USD 0.16 LOWER AT USD 34.65

Crude prices traded subdued and choppy after the strong gains on Monday that resulted from a market-wide reflation trade. Part of the recent strength is likely a function of short-covering ahead of June contract expiry, Citi notes, as several speculators likely grew short positions in the wake of last month’s WTI expiry, in hope of another move towards the negative prices seen back then. Citi says that participants are taking bullish enthusiasm from the front-month spread backwardation in WTI as signal of growing tightness in the physical market, as well as looking past near term demand weakness as a temporary factor, as evidenced by weak data points being shrugged off. News flow in the energy space was light today, although US Energy Secretary Brouillette said, in an Axios Q&A talking about US energy companies, that if these companies borrowed too much,  or borrowed at a ‘bad’ rate, those decisions are going to have consequences, and the government should not step in to change the ultimate outcome. Brouillette also said that he thinks as demand comes back, we will see increasing production return in the US once again. Looking ahead, bulls will be looking for further signs of physical market tightness in this week’s US inventories. Current expectations (bbls): crude +1.2mln, Cushing -5.1mln, distillate +1.4mln, gasoline -2.1mln.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -1.07% at 2922, NDQ -0.36% at 9299, DJIA -1.59% at 24,207

SECTORS: Energy -2.89%, Financials -2.52%, Real Estate -1.85%, Cons Stpl -1.75%, Utilities -1.7%, Industrials -1.28%, Health -1.21%, Materials -1%, Communication Svs -0.41%, Technology -0.4%, Cons Disc -0.09%           

EARNINGS: Walmart opened higher after beating on both the top- and bottom-lines, saying that unprecedented demand for products across multiple categories led to strong top-line results, and US comp sales were above estimates, and accelerated in mid-April owing to government stimulus cheques. It said net sales and operating results were significantly affected by the outbreak of COVID-19, and it has withdrawn FY guidance. Certain incremental costs negatively affected operating income, including costs associated with enhanced wages and benefits as well as safety and sanitation. Company will discontinue Jet.com. Home Depot (HD) open in the red (6.8% Dow weight, 1.1% SPX weight), after it missed on EPS, beat on revenue; comparable sales were above consensus; dividend was maintained; HD said that while sales trends were strong at the end of Q1 and into the first two weeks of Q2, it was suspending Fy20 guidance due to COVID uncertainty. HD took actions to support staff in light of COVID and incurred a total of approximately USD 850mln of pre-tax expenses, equaling around 0.60 per diluted share. Baidu (BIDU) saw top and bottom-line beats and solid guidance. Advanced Auto Parts (AAP) missed on EPS and revenue, although it noted that its comp sales improved week by week in May.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Facebook (FB) launched a new product, Facebook Shops which initially weighed on Shopify (SHOP) however the new product is actually powered by SHOP and thus a reversal was seen, and SHOP gained. Spotify (SPOT) announced a multi-year licensing deal for the Joe Rogan Podcast. Nasdaq is to release new restrictions on IPO’s in a move that makes it harder to Chinese companies to debut on its stock exchange, according to sources. Reports in WWD suggest Amazon (AMZN) is eyeing JCPenney (JCP) and the two are apparently in talks over a deal. However, trading is to be suspended on NYSE. United Airlines (UAL) notes as of May it has seen a reduction in customer cancellations, while Southwest (LUV) announced it has experienced a modest improvement in June bookings and April capacity was -58% and Delta (DAL) are running more flights to prevent overcrowded planes. SoftBank (9984 JT) is to sell a sizeable stake in T-Mobile (TMUS) in a secondary offering, according to sources. Comcast’s (CMCSA) NBCUniversal is being sued by SmileDirectClub (SDC). Morderna (MRNA) is said to be offering around USD 187.5mln of common shares at a price range of USD 75-77.50/shr to fund capital needs for its MRNA-1273 COVID vaccine; note that a Stat News report citing health experts highlighted that the positive news on a vaccine from Monday warrants caution due to the low sample size of the study.

FX WRAP

DXY slides while risk sensitive currencies outperform

USD: The dollar continued its decline, despite subdued risk appetite in pre-market trade on the back of US/WHO/China headline risk, but as the US session progressed the buck rose off its lows. Technicians are eyeing the May low of 99.239 on the DXY, which seems to have held in today’s session with DXY finding support within a whisker above the level. Capital Economics believes that although uncertainty on the economic recovery should continue to support the dollar, the risk asset recovery and fall in US interest rates will start to pull the currency down in the weeks ahead.

EUR: The single currency continues to benefit from the Franco-German EU recovery fund proposal, while dollar weakness was also supportive. Analysts are cognizant of the proposal given that they still needs to be backed by al 27 member states, and some nations like Austria have already pushed back on the idea, while those like Netherlands have previously objected the grants (vs loans) and “coronabonds”. Analysts at Citi note that the announcement reinforces its expectation that pro-EU forces will avoid a major escalation in break up risks and that it is in fitting with their view that near term risks are skewed to a positive surprise on the plan. The bank however remains bearish on the currency as there are significant uncertainties and expect some pushback to the idea; Citi look to fade the EUR rally.

GBP: Sterling continued to rise today given the risk appetite of the currency with other cyclicals also performing well amid a falling dollar however risks remain with Brexit talks yielding little to no progress with the June extension deadline approaching. Elsewhere, there is a wide consensus the BoE are to expand its QE programme by USD 200bln at its June meeting. JPMorgan notes they are selling GBP on this bounce against both the USD and EUR, as UK issues have not gone away while there is positive news elsewhere, although the desk caveats with more risk-on could see cable push higher, but overall it is selling into the recent strength.

JPY: The yen continues to see downside against the dollar as risk improves, albeit not to the same extend as yesterday given some concerns overnight with the US, WHO, and China. Losses are only modest, however, and ING points out the “heavily reduced USD advantage” and expect to see USDJPY at 105 this summer.

NZD: Risk sensitive currencies continue to perform well with particular outperformance in NZD; commentary from RBNZ deputy Governor Bascand noted that no decision had been made on negative rates (after the RBNZ left the door open for them in its latest meeting) while Assistant Governor Hawkesby suggested there is no need to adjust stimulus in wake of the budget but is open to all tools, adding there may not be the need to increase the size of its QE programme (recently increased the size to NZD 60bln).

AUD: The Aussie also performed well on risk, but not to the same extent as its Antipodean counterpart. The latest RBA minutes saw members assess the best course of action was to maintain current policy while it highlighted what is required before policy is adjusted “It would not increase the cash rate target until progress is made towards full employment and it is confident inflation will be sustainably within the 2-3% target band”, and 3-year yields would be maintained until progress was made towards its full employment and inflation target. Westpac believes the “progress towards” can mean if the bank is confident that any move towards full employment will be sustained, it can remove the target for the three-year yield. And WPAC also believes that the 3-year target rate will be lifted to around 0.4% during 2022, although the overnight cash rate will not be lifted before the end of 2023 and dismiss the possibility of negative rates.

EMFX: The majority of EMFX traded in line with risk appetite, apart from the BRL which was weaker on the day with Brazil becoming one of the most infected nations as it now has more COVID cases than the UK while lingering worries over the political state continue to add concern. Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs cut its Brazil 2020 GDP growth forecast to -7.4% from -3.4%. Petro currencies (MXN, RUB) were also firmer although MXN led the way. TRY, however, outperformed, with USDTRY seeing lows of 6.75 despite Treasury Officials announcing they are still in discussions for swap lines and that talks of a deal with the BoE and BoJ were not true, dismissing earlier reports.

TREASURY WRAP: US T-Note futures (M0) settle 8+ ticks higher at 138-27+
analysis_details:
Treasury yields were lower across the curve, and major curve spreads were mixed on Tuesday; 2s unchanged at 17bp, 10s –3bp at 71bp, and 30s -2bp at 144bp. After the chunky UST sell off on Monday, real money was said to have lifting offers across the curve in the APAC session (yield thirsty Japanese funds have been noted as the marginal buyer in recent weeks as FX hedging costs declined). However, as US participants returned, hedge fund reallocation flows were said by one desk to have continued to exert pressure on USTs, creating somewhat of a tug-of-war with buyers in Asia. Some suggested that the long-end underperformance was a function of concession heading into Wednesday’s sale of new 20-year bonds.

US 20-YEAR BOND AUCTION PREVIEW: At its quarterly refunding announcement, the US Treasury said it would finally issue its new 20-year maturities on 20th May, for a size of USD 20bln (cue ‘20-20-20’ “jokes”). The size was bigger than anticipated (USD 12-14bln was touted), and with heavier supply at the long-end of the curve, combined with no announcement of a 4- or 6-year tenor, resulted in sharp curve steepening in the wake of the announcement, though this has been pared somewhat as risk conditions soften in recent trade. UBS estimates that the market has cheapened the 20-year sector, noting that the sector was cheap versus 10s30s curve as well, although now seems fair; hence, UBS says, it is cheap outright. “In general, we think the sector has already been cheap due to less liquidity and the fact that the Fed owns a large portion of the issues in the 20-year sector so its future purchases are limited.” The bank argues that, given where the 3.375% May 2044 bond is trading, fair value for the 20-year issue is implied at around 1.27%; If we assume 1-2bps of liquidity premia for the new issue, the issue is likely to trade at 1.26%, the bank writes, speculating that the issue should see strong demand since a lot of indexers and Asset Liability Management hedgers will need to buy it. “You can pick-up a lot of yield as the steepest part of 10s30s curve (around 70bps) where fair value is actually 10s20s curve (60bps),” UBS says, noting that the 30-year bond has a duration of 23-years, and comparatively, the 20-year will have a duration of 17.6yrs (5.4yrs shorter), and therefore, it makes more sense to extend duration with a 20-year than a 30- year. “Clearly, if the roll opens cheap to our fair-value estimate, we recommend owning the WI vs comparator,” UBS writes, “post-auction on Wednesday May 20th, into month-end, we recommend putting on 10s20s curve flatteners,” adding that we are likely to see larger than normal index extension because of heavy long-end issuance this month.”

analysis_details: Crude prices traded subdued and choppy after the strong gains on Monday that resulted from a market-wide reflation trade. Part of the recent strength is likely a function of short-covering ahead of June contract expiry, Citi notes, as several speculators likely grew short positions in the wake of last month’s WTI expiry, in hope of another move towards the negative prices seen back then. Citi says that participants are taking bullish enthusiasm from the front-month spread backwardation in WTI as signal of growing tightness in the physical market, as well as looking past near term demand weakness as a temporary factor, as evidenced by weak data points being shrugged off. News flow in the energy space was light today, although US Energy Secretary Brouillette said, in an Axios Q&A talking about US energy companies, that if these companies borrowed too much,  or borrowed at a ‘bad’ rate, those decisions are going to have consequences, and the government should not step in to change the ultimate outcome. Brouillette also said that he thinks as demand comes back, we will see increasing production return in the US once again. Looking ahead, bulls will be looking for further signs of physical market tightness in this week’s US inventories. subject: FX WRAP: DXY slides while risk sensitive currencies outperform
analysis_details:
USD: The dollar continued its decline, despite subdued risk appetite in pre-market trade on the back of US/WHO/China headline risk, but as the US session progressed the buck rose off its lows. Technicians are eyeing the May low of 99.239 on the DXY, which seems to have held in today’s session with DXY finding support within a whisker above the level. Capital Economics believes that although uncertainty on the economic recovery should continue to support the dollar, the risk asset recovery and fall in US interest rates will start to pull the currency down in the weeks ahead.

EUR: The single currency continues to benefit from the Franco-German EU recovery fund proposal, while dollar weakness was also supportive. Analysts are cognizant of the proposal given that they still needs to be backed by al 27 member states, and some nations like Austria have already pushed back on the idea, while those like Netherlands have previously objected the grants (vs loans) and “coronabonds”. Analysts at Citi note that the announcement reinforces its expectation that pro-EU forces will avoid a major escalation in break up risks and that it is in fitting with their view that near term risks are skewed to a positive surprise on the plan. The bank however remains bearish on the currency as there are significant uncertainties and expect some pushback to the idea; Citi look to fade the EUR rally.

GBP: Sterling continued to rise today given the risk appetite of the currency with other cyclicals also performing well amid a falling dollar however risks remain with Brexit talks yielding little to no progress with the June extension deadline approaching. Elsewhere, there is a wide consensus the BoE are to expand its QE programme by USD 200bln at its June meeting. JPMorgan notes they are selling GBP on this bounce against both the USD and EUR, as UK issues have not gone away while there is positive news elsewhere, although the desk caveats with more risk-on could see cable push higher, but overall it is selling into the recent strength.

JPY: The yen continues to see downside against the dollar as risk improves, albeit not to the same extend as yesterday given some concerns overnight with the US, WHO, and China. Losses are only modest, however, and ING points out the “heavily reduced USD advantage” and expect to see USDJPY at 105 this summer.

NZD:  Risk sensitive currencies continue to perform well with particular outperformance in NZD; commentary from RBNZ deputy Governor Bascand noted that no decision had been made on negative rates (after the RBNZ left the door open for them in its latest meeting) while Assistant Governor Hawkesby suggested there is no need to adjust stimulus in wake of the budget but is open to all tools, adding there may not be the need to increase the size of its QE programme (recently increased the size to NZD 60bln).

AUD: The Aussie also performed well on risk, but not to the same extent as its Antipodean counterpart. The latest RBA minutes saw members assess the best course of action was to maintain current policy while it highlighted what is required before policy is adjusted “It would not increase the cash rate target until progress is made towards full employment and it is confident inflation will be sustainably within the 2-3% target band”, and 3-year yields would be maintained until progress was made towards its full employment and inflation target. Westpac believes the “progress towards” can mean if the bank is confident that any move towards full employment will be sustained, it can remove the target for the three-year yield. And WPAC also believes that the 3-year target rate will be lifted to around 0.4% during 2022, although the overnight cash rate will not be lifted before the end of 2023 and dismiss the possibility of negative rates.

EMFX: The majority of EMFX traded in line with risk appetite, apart from the BRL which was weaker on the day with Brazil becoming one of the most infected nations as it now has more COVID cases than the UK while lingering worries over the political state continue to add concern. Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs cut its Brazil 2020 GDP growth forecast to -7.4% from -3.4%. Petro currencies (MXN, RUB) were also firmer although MXN led the way. TRY, however, outperformed, with USDTRY seeing lows of 6.75 despite Treasury Officials announcing they are still in discussions for swap lines and that talks of a deal with the BoE and BoJ were not true, dismissing earlier reports.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Yen and Kiwi flank the G10 ranks, with Greenback rangy in between
content:
JPY/NZD/AUD

The Yen is underperforming across the board amidst another rebound in US Treasury alongside other core global bond yields from recent lows, and with curves still braced or making room for heavy issuancef. Usd/Jpy surpassed prior mtd peaks around 107.77 on the way through 108.00 to test mid-April highs at 108.08 before paring back on a broad downturn in risk sentiment, but a close above the big figure could see technical momentum build further towards the 200 DMA (108.27) ahead of Friday’s BoJ meeting on bank lending measures already signalled by Governor Kuroda last month. Conversely, the Kiwi has inched beyond 0.6100 vs its US counterpart on a combination less dovish sounding commentary from the RBNZ (Deputy Governor Bascand advocating a wait-and-see stance overnight) and an element of ‘safe-haven’ positioning via the Aud/Nzd cross in view of heightened trade tensions between Australia and China over the former’s push for a full COVID-19 probe. As a result, the Aussie reversed gains above 1.0800 to sub-1.0750 relative to its Antipodean peer and Aud/Usd pulled up short of multi-tops circa 0.6570 yet again.

GBP/NOK/CAD/MXN/RUB

Sterling derived some early support and traction from a rather timely announcement of a new favoured nation tariff scheme to replace the EU’s Common External Tariff regime after the Brexit transition that will remove Gbp 30 bn taxes on imports from the start of next year. The headlines hit in tandem with a bigger than anticipated jump in the UK claimant count and marginally weaker than consensus earnings to the benefit of the Pound, as Cable sustained its recovery from sub-1.2200 lows and Eur/Gbp backed off within a 0.8958-16 range. Meanwhile, strength in the Norwegian Crown, Canadian Dollar, Mexican Peso and Russian Rouble emanated mainly from oil maintaining its buoyancy into the June WTI crude contract expiry in stark contrast to the collapse in May and unprecedented/uncharted plunge below parity when the May future rolled off. Indeed, the Nok resisted persistent Eur strength and comments from Norges Bank Governor Olsen highlighting room to manoeuvre on the economic policy side of the equation even if the depo rate has hit a floor, while the Rub took dovish CBR commentary and softer than forecast Q1 GDP in stride.

EUR/DXY

The Euro extended post-EU recovery fund and joint debt issuance gains to 1.0976 vs the Buck and 118.00+ against the Yen, but failed to reach 1.1100 and 118.50 respectively after French Finance Minister Le Maire dampened some euphoria by underlining that the extra Eur500 bn cash will not be available until 2021. However, the Greenback failed to take advantage due to the aforementioned vs most major rivals and the bulk of EM currencies, as the index pivoted 99.500 between 99.735-225 extremes with no independent impetus from Fed chair Powell or US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin given pre-releases of their testimonies yesterday.

EM 

The Lira and Rand continue their renaissance regardless of disappointment for the Try in terms of CBRT efforts to try and secure swap lines still not proving successful, while the Zar got some encouragement from better than expected SA mining production data to offset a drop in manufacturing output in the run up to Thursday’s SARB policy meeting that is tipped to culminate in a 50 bp rate cut.

US EQUITY OPEN: US indices see a subdued open although gains in tech and BIDU earnings support NDX
analysis_details:
WHAT’S GOING ON: Monday’s optimism seems to have cooled, and major European bourses gave up gains after the open. Further prickly US/China headlines were partly responsible this morning, although the S&P 500 Emini has been gradually easing after an overnight report that Nasdaq may unveil new restrictions on IPOs, which will make it more difficult for some Chinese companies to list on the exchange. SPX and DJI open lower, NDX higher. The VIX has ticked up but remains sub-30. The Treasury curve is steeper slightly, though yields are lower across the curve (note: The Fed’s single operation in the short-end today is sized above the daily average). The Dollar Index is softer for the second day (just), towards the bottom of its May range (May low 99.239 for your reference); the buck’s weakness is allowing risk-sensitive FX and EMFX to rally. Commodity FX is also higher despite crude benchmarks being mixed. Gold trades slightly higher. The focus continues to remain on reopening economies, progress on vaccines and treatments, commentary from corporates that shows the process of recovering is underway, and of course stimulus measures (Powell and Mnuchin testify to Senate later today; BOJ to take more measures to support banks; Europe’s relief package proposals are a positive development on Monday, in that they will offer grants not loans, though will likely face some hurdles among national governments due to proposals of joint debt issuance).

SECTORS: Sectors open mostly in the red with underperformance in Energy and Financials after solid gains yesterday (+7.6 and +5.3%, respectively). Note, crude prices and yields are both modestly lower today. Technology outperforms and is the only sector in the green, with heavy weights Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) both up slightly at the open.  Tech gains sees NDX outperform, which is also boosted by gains in Baidu (BIDU) post earnings.

EARNINGS: Walmart opened higher after beating on both the top- and bottom-lines, saying that unprecedented demand for products across multiple categories led to strong top-line results, and US comp sales were above estimates, and accelerated in mid-April owing to government stimulus cheques. It said net sales and operating results were significantly affected by the outbreak of COVID-19, and it has withdrawn FY guidance. Certain incremental costs negatively affected operating income, including costs associated with enhanced wages and benefits as well as safety and sanitation. Company will discontinue Jet.com. Home Depot (HD) open in the red (6.8% Dow weight, 1.1% SPX weight), after it missed on EPS, beat on revenue; comparable sales were above consensus; dividend was maintained; HD said that while sales trends were strong at the end of Q1 and into the first two weeks of Q2, it was suspending Fy20 guidance due to COVID uncertainty. HD took actions to support staff in light of COVID and incurred a total of approximately USD 850mln of pre-tax expenses, equaling around 0.60 per diluted share. Baidu (BIDU) saw top and bottom-line beats and solid guidance. Advanced Auto Parts (AAP) missed on EPS and revenue, although it noted that its comp sales improved week by week in May.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Nasdaq is to release new restrictions on IPO’s in a move that makes it harder to Chinese companies to debut on its stock exchange, according to sources. Reports in WWD suggest Amazon (AMZN) is eyeing JCPenney (JCP) and the two are apparently in talks over a deal. However, trading is to be suspended on NYSE. United Airlines (UAL) notes as of May it has seen a reduction in customer cancelations, while Southwest (LUV) announced it has experienced a modest improvement in June bookings and April capacity was -58% and Delta (DAL) are running more flights to prevent overcrowded planes. SoftBank (9984 JT) is to sell a sizeable stake in T-Mobile (TMUS) in a secondary offering, according to sources. Comcast’s (CMCSA) NBCUniversal is being sued by SmileDirectClub (SDC). Morderna (MRNA) is said to be offering around USD 187.5mln of common shares at a price range of USD 75-77.50/shr to fund capital needs for its MRNA-1273 COVID vaccine.

ES KEY LEVELS: The S&P 500 Emini took out the April high in overnight trade, rising to 2,976.25, bringing the 200dma just under 3,000 into focus; however, the air remains thin at those levels, and ES has fallen back to just above the key 2,930 region. To the topside, 2,950-2,955 is worth keeping an eye from a valuation perspective (consensus FY20 expected EPS 138 x 21.4 p/e; FY21 EPS expected 163 x 18.1 p/e). On the downside, desks are continuing to watch 2,930 (61.8% Feb hi-Mar lo) and the region around 2,900, and then Monday’s low around 2,850.

SHORT-TERM TRADERS LIQUIDATING SHORTS: Nomura’s quant team thinks many speculative investors have had to reconsider the 'sell in May' play, or trades based on a stock market 'double-dip'. The bank suggests that short-term traders are liquidating short positions in US equities, and it believes that these investors think the 'sell in May' opportunity has passed. It also observes that fundamentally focused global macro hedge funds are being pressed into covering shorts in DM equities again; these funds have been trading on the assumption that DM equity markets are in for a double dip may be facing pressure, not only from the swing back to improvement in the economic surprise index, but also increasing news reports suggesting that a COVID-19 vaccine may become widely available sooner than previously expected, Nomura says. However, global macro hedge funds have kept their net exposure to DM equities steady at a fairly low level, and Nomura sees no sign of across-the-board buying push that one might expect if investors were feeling FOMO, and the bank does not expect there to be many of these investors inclined to sell the rally in DM equities, unless some unexpected market-negative news pops up. Meanwhile, the quants observe that CTAs appear to have already put a stop to their exits from long positions in NASDAQ 100 futures, which have been holding up well, though it believes that these CTAs may become net buyers again around 5th June, “but it is possible that they could start accumulating longs again even sooner than that,” Nomura says.

subject: Bank of America May 2020 Fund Manager Survey finds that investors are still extremely bearish
content:
• THE RECOVERY: The survey finds only 10% of fund managers expect a V-shaped recovery (with any new vaccine breakthrough the likely catalyst), and 25% expect a new bull-market However, 75% expect a W-shape or U-shaped recovery, and 68% see a bear market rally. The survey also finds that growth expectations have jumped, although investors do not expect the global manufacturing PMI to rise above the 50.0 until November (currently 40.0). In terms of the post-COVID economy, fund managers say the biggest structural shift may be supply chain reshoring, according to 68% of those surveyed; 44% say protectionism, while 42% said higher taxes.
  • WHAT FMs THINK CORPORATES SHOULD DO: 73% of fund managers think companies should cut debt levels, 15% think they should boost capex, while 7% think corporatez should raise buyback and dividend levels.
  • ALLOCATIONS: Fund manager cash levels are at 5.7%, down from 5.9% BofA notes, though well above the 4.7% 10-year average. The FMS shows bond allocations rising to highest since July 2009, long US/short Europe the highest since June 2012, and investors are now short emerging markets for the first time since Sept 2018, and are holding record longs in healthcare.
  • TRADES: The survey suggests the pain trade for stocks and credit is still upwards, which BofA says is consistent with the SPX above 3,020, and high yield spreads under 650bps. Investors see the biggest tail risk as a second wave of infections. The most crowded trade is considered long US technology and growth stocks, according to 60% of those surveyed, and BofA says that the last time this many fund managers expected value to underperform growth was December 2007. BofA says investors are looking to play the upside via long EM debt-short US tech, long energy-short healthcare, long Europe-short US; investors are also looking to play structural reshoring theme via long value-short growth, long small cap-short large cap.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 19th May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Nasdaq is to release new restrictions on IPO’s in a move that makes it harder to Chinese companies to debut on its stock exchange - sources
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) Q1 2020 (USD): EPS 1.18 (exp. 1.12); Revenue 134.6bln (exp. 132.74bln)
  • JC Penney (JCP) (Consumer Discretionary/Multiline retail) - reports in WWD suggest Amazon (AMZN) is eyeing the retailer and the two are apparently in talks over some kind of deal.

May 19th, 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1400BST/0800CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

  • Of note for US-listed Chinese ADR’s (BABA, BIDU, JD, TCEHY, TME), Nasdaq is to release new restrictions on IPO’s in a move that makes it harder to Chinese companies to debut on its stock exchange, according to sources. Nasdaq did not mention any specific names, but it is a move being done to tackle concerns regarding Chinese IPO lack of accounting transparency and close ties to powerful insiders, the sources added. Note, it appears to be only to those looking to IPO, but it is another step against China from the US amid the escalations between both sides. Elsewhere, it has been reported that Nasdaq has delivered notice to Luckin Coffee (LK) that it must delist from the exchange, according to sources; LK have been halted for several weeks after investigators found it fabricated sales.
  • Of note for Automakers (GM, F, TSLA, FCAU), EU registrations of new passenger cars -76.3% Y/Y.

DOW JONES

  • Home Depot (HD) (Consumer Discretionary/Home Improvement Retail) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 2.08 (exp. 2.27), Revenue 28.3bln (exp. 27.54bln); suspends 2020 outlook. Same-store sales: Home Depot (US): 7.5% (Q1 exp. 5.00%; Q2 exp. 1.25%), Home Depot: 6.4% (exp. 4.5%). Declared a quarterly dividend of USD 1.50/shr. Suspends FY guidance, notes it was a strong quarter with the trend continuing into May. Strong same-store sales were offset by the USD 0.60 hit taken to EPS on the USD 850mln COVID related expenses.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) Q1 2020 (USD): EPS 1.18 (exp. 1.12); Revenue 134.6bln (exp. 132.74bln); withdraws FY guidance. Walmart US comp: +10.0% (exp. 8.84%), Walmart International: 29.8bln (exp. 29.04bln). Incurred USD 900mln COVID-related expenses in the quarter. Expects to see significant top-line FX headwinds. Says unprecedented demand for products across multiple categories led to strong top-line results. It noted how sales accelerated in the middle of April thanks to the stimulus checks. Walmart added that certain incremental costs negatively affected operating income, including costs associated with enhanced wages and benefits as well as safety and sanitation. WMT is to discontinue Jet.com.
  • JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) (Financials/Diversified Banks) CEO Dimon announced a COVID-19 update, the bank is delaying mortgage payments for homeowners for at least three months and they will not be charged a late fee or penalty during this time frame. It notes it has helped over 1.5mln customer accounts, is working to help clients, helped raise USD 664bln in IG financing, and provided USD 104bln of high yield financing. JPM has funded over USD 30bln to 250,000 businesses. In March & April, it approved over USD 45bln in new credit for clients.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) head of streaming operations Mayer resigns to become TikTok's CEO.

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) warehouses in France have re-opened with 30% capacity, according to union workers.
  • Baidu Inc (BIDU) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 1.25 (exp. 0.57), Revenue 3.18bln (exp. 3.1bln). DAU’s +28% Y/Y to 288mln, Q2 revenue view 3.5-3.9bln (exp. 3.62bln).
  • Comcast Corp. (CMCSA) (Communication Services/Cable & Satellite) NBCUniversal is being sued by SmileDirectClub (SDC) for USD 2.8bln for allegedly defamatory news reports about its treatment methods.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) China car registrations fell to 4633 units in April from 12709 units in March, a 64% decline.
  • T-Mobile (TMUS) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) is to have a sizeable stake sold by SoftBank (9984 JT) in a secondary offering, according to CNBC citing sources.
  • United Continental Holdings (UAL) (Industrials/Airlines) CEO announced the co. has not laid any workers off or furloughed them, noting some have taken voluntary leave to avoid this from happening. UAL also announced it is not purchasing any new planes and they will not build capacity until demand is back. Elsewhere, it announced in April it experienced gross bookings that were down 95% Y/Y, and as of May 18th, it has seen a reduction in customer cancellations and a moderate improvement in the US and some international destinations.

S&P 500

  • Advance Auto Parts (AAP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automotive Retail) Q1 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.91 (exp. 1.75), revenue 2.7bln (exp. 2.74bln). SSS -9.3%, notes comp sales improved each week in May. It does not provide guidance. It also announced it drew down USD 500mln from revolving credit facilities in Q1.
  • Darden Restaurants (DRI) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) Q4 to date same restaurant sales -47.9%; notes it begun reopening restaurants between 25-50% capacity. Olive Garden SSS -39.4%, LongHorn Steakhouse -45.8%, Fine Dining -63.1%, Other -65.5%
  • Delta Air Lines Inc. (DAL) (Industrials/Airlines) announced its plans to add flights to keep planes at no more than 60% full capacity until at least July, according to sources.
  • Helmerich & Payne (HP) (Energy/Oil & Gas Drilling) is to be replaced in the S&P 500 by West Pharmaceutical Services (WST) on May 22nd.
  • Kohl's Corp. (KSS) (Consumer Discretionary/General Merchandise Stores) Q1 20 (USD): Adj. EPS -3.50 (may not compare to exp. 0.40), Revenue 2.43bln (exp. 3.83bln); does not report SSS due to store closures.
  • Macerich (MAC) (Real Estate/Retail REITs) announced 20 of its retail properties are fully open.
  • Southwest Airlines (LUV) (Industrials/Airlines) April load factor of 8% with April capacity -58%, notes it experienced modest improvement in June bookings. Currently holds in cash and short-term investments roughly USD 13bln. Preliminary operating revenues -90% to -95%, May operating revenue view -85% to -90%.

OTHER

  • Carvana (CVNA) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) announced a 5mln share offering of its class A common stock and is planning to use the proceeds for general business purposes.

  • JC Penney (JCP) (Consumer Discretionary/Multiline retail) trading is to be suspended on NYSE. Meanwhile, reports in WWD suggest Amazon (AMZN) is eyeing the retailer and the two are apparently in talks over some kind of deal.
  • Moderna (MRNA) (Health Care/Biotechnology) said to be offering around USD 187.5mln of common shares at a share price range of USD 75.00-77.50 to fund working capital needs related from its COVID-19 vaccine, MRNA-1273.
  • NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) (Information Technology/Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) announced its RFFE solution is now designed into Xiaomi Mi 10 5G smartphones.
  • Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) announced wildfire victims voted for USD 13.5bln settlement offer, which puts the co. in a favourable position to exit chapter 11 on its preferred times, according to WSJ.

subject: NEC Director Kudlow says administration still to decide on what coronavirus relief measures it might back
ANALYSIS: US housing starts drop 30% in April; likely the trough, Pantheon says
analysis_details:
• Data showed that housing starts declined to 891k in April (-30.2%), in line with the consensus. Analysts had expected the downside given COVID-related lockdowns. Pantheon Macroeconomics argues that these data will likely mark the floor, and May data will be better, and June better still, although it says a return to February levels will take some time.
  • “Usually, new sales lead permits, and permits lead starts, but the lags appear to have been compressed by the suddenness of the Covid hit,” the consultancy writes, “these data suggest that next week’s new home sales number for April will be about 450K, down from 627K in March and 741K in February.”
  • It also notes that mortgage applications have recovered by more than half of the fall seen since the lockdown, while searches on google for “new homes” is trending around the pre-COVID peak; “It seems that most of the people who have lost their jobs were not near-term prospective homebuyers,” Pantheon says, “we’re expecting a robust recovery in all the housing market indicators over the late spring and summer.”

Fixed and FX latest: core debt under more pressure, but Dollar off worst levels
content: Gilts appear to have been the major target for bond bears in recent trade and are now testing 137.00 ahead of late April Liffe lows (at 136.94 vs 136.74 from April 27), while Bunds hold just above similar downside ‘support’ protecting 172.00 (172.09 from April 28 vs 172.26 Eurex nadir so far), but US Treasures are also seeing some knock-on declines with the long end back below parity and the curve flipping from a flatter bias to steepening again. Mixed US housing data has been largely shrugged off awaiting the Wall Street open and Fed chair Powell alongside Kashkari before Rosengren later, but the Buck is nursing losses across the board and forging further gains vs the Yen towards 108.00 after breaching recent highs and clearing decent option expiries. Indeed, the DXY has bounced from 99.225 to just shy of 99.500, albeit still some way down from 99.735 highs.

subject: Germany Foreign Minister Maas is confident that he can convince other EU nations over the Coronavirus Recovery Fund
analysis_details:
• On Monday, France and Germany announced joint proposals of a EUR 500bln European Recovery Fund, that would be offering grants not loans to nations, that would be paid back through the EU Budget; there would also be an element of joint issuance.
  • Analysts note that while the development is a positive, and a precedent is set where joint issuance can take place, the recovery fund would become effective in 2021. Additionally, the proposals would still need to be voted on unanimously by national governments, which is where hurdles may appear; Some of the Northern European states (Netherlands, Austria, Denmark and Sweden) have suggested that they were more in favour of loans rather than grants, while joint debt issuance has worried some of these hawks.
  • Official EU proposal will be unveiled on May 27th. European Council President Michel has to broker final accord – with meeting yet to be scheduled

subject: Japanese finance minister Aso says G7 finance leaders held a teleconference discussing new virus issues, including restarting of economic activity; Japan to cooperate with other G7 nations to achieve strong global growth
PRE-MARKET THEMES: Risk pares back Monday’s optimism; Powell, Mnuchin testify at 10am ET
analysis_details:
WHAT’S GOING ON: Monday’s optimism seems to have cooled, and major European bourses gave up gains after the open. Further prickly US/China headlines were partly responsible this morning, although the S&P 500 Emini has been gradually easing after an overnight report that Nasdaq may unveil new restrictions on IPOs, which will make it more difficult for some Chinese companies to list on the exchange. The VIX has ticked up, but remains sub-30. The Treasury curve is bull-flattening moderately after Monday's bear steepener (note: the Fed’s single operation in the short-end today is sized above the daily average). The Dollar Index is softer for the second day, towards the bottom of its May range (May low 99.239 for your reference); the buck’s weakness is allowing risk-sensitive FX and EMFX to rally. Commodity FX is also higher despite crude benchmarks being mixed. Gold trades slightly higher. The focus continues to remain on reopening economies, progress on vaccines and treatments, commentary from corporates that shows the process of recovering is underway, and of course stimulus measures (Powell and Mnuchin testify to Senate later today; BOJ to take more measures to support banks; Europe’s relief package proposals are a positive development on Monday, in that they will offer grants not loans, though will likely face some hurdles among national governments due to proposals of joint debt issuance).

ES KEY LEVELS: The S&P 500 Emini took out the April high in overnight trade, rising to 2,976.25, bringing the 200dma just under 3,000 into focus; however, the air remains thin at those levels, and ES has fallen back to just above the key 2,930 region. To the topside, 2,950-2,955 is worth keeping an eye from a valuation perspective (consensus FY20 expected EPS 138 x 21.4 p/e; FY21 EPS expected 163 x 18.1 p/e). On the downside, desks are continuing to watch 2,930 (61.8% Feb hi-Mar lo) and the region around 2,900, and then Monday’s low around 2,850.

WMT/HD EARNINGS: Home Depot (HD) lower in pre-market action (6.8% Dow weight, 1.1% SPX weight), missed on EPS, beat on revenue; comparable sales were above consensus; dividend was maintained; HD said that while sales trends were strong at the end of Q1 and into the first two weeks of Q2, it was suspending Fy20 guidance due to COVID uncertainty. HD took actions taken to support staff in light of COVID, and incurred a total of approximately USD 850mln of pre-tax expenses, equalling around 0.60 per diluted share. Walmart is higher in pre-market action, beating on both the top- and bottom-lines, saying that unprecedented demand for products across multiple categories led to strong top-line results, and US comp sales were above estimates, and accelerated in mid-April owing to government stimulus cheques. It said net sales and operating results were significantly affected by the outbreak of COVID-19, and it has withdrawn FY guidance. Certain incremental costs negatively affected operating income, including costs associated with enhanced wages and benefits as well as safety and sanitation. Company will discontinue Jet.com.

POWELL AT 10AM EDT: This week’s testimony by Chair Powell on Tuesday, the meeting minutes from the FOMC’s April confab on Wednesday, and the Fed Listens event to be attended by Powell on Thursday are not likely to reveal much by way of new information, given the proximity of the recent meeting and the subsequent commentary from Fed Chair Powell. Accordingly, the message from these events is likely to be a reiteration that the Fed will take action it deems necessary towards supporting the economy and aiding its bounce back from COVID, although that is not likely to include negative rates at this stage; the Fed is also likely to again call on fiscal authorities to help with the heavy lifting. Full preview here. 

BOJ: On the subject of central banks and stimulus, the BOJ said it would hold an off-schedule meeting on 22nd May to discuss further funding measures for the banking sector. In April, the BOJ said it would create a new scheme as soon as possible that rewards financial firms for lending to smaller companies hit by the pandemic. In April, Kuroda said the BOJ would finance loans that commercial banks extend to small businesses via the government programmes, and the central bank would also pay 0.1% interest to commercial banks that boost such lending.

SHORT-TERM TRADERS LIQUIDATING SHORTS: Nomura’s quant team thinks many speculative investors have had to reconsider the 'sell in May' play, or trades based on a stock market 'double-dip'. The bank suggests that short-term traders are liquidating short positions in US equities, and it believes that these investors think the 'sell in May' opportunity has passed. It also observes that fundamentally focused global macro hedge funds are being pressed into covering shorts in DM equities again; these funds have been trading on the assumption that DM equity markets are in for a double dip may be facing pressure, not only from the swing back to improvement in the economic surprise index, but also increasing news reports suggesting that a COVID-19 vaccine may become widely available sooner than previously expected, Nomura says. However, global macro hedge funds have kept their net exposure to DM equities steady at a fairly low level, and Nomura sees no sign of across-the-board buying push that one might expect if investors were feeling FOMO, and the bank does not expect there to be many of these investors inclined to sell the rally in DM equities, unless some unexpected market-negative news pops up. Meanwhile, the quants observe that CTAs appear to have already put a stop to their exits from long positions in NASDAQ 100 futures, which have been holding up well, though it believes that these CTAs may become net buyers again around 5th June, “but it is possible that they could start accumulating longs again even sooner than that,” Nomura says.
